title: 103_s2259
content: The Act is titled the "Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation Grand Coulee Dam Settlement Act" and includes definitions. The Act defines key terms such as Administrator, Bonneville Power Administration, Dam (Grand Coulee Dam), and Confederated Tribes v. United States. The case "Confederated Tribes v. United States" is pending in the United States Court of Federal Claims, transferred from the Indian Claims Commission. A minor is defined as a child under 18 years old. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Settlement Agreement" pertains to the agreement between the United States and the Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation to settle the tribe's claims. The "Tribe" is defined as the Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation, a federally recognized Indian tribe. The text chunk "SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE." is a section that outlines the findings and purpose of a document or agreement. The Congress finds that the Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation have a pending action against the United States seeking damages under the Indian Claims Commission Act related to fair dealings after the construction of the Grand Coulee Dam. The potential liability of the United States is substantial in this matter. The Congress finds that the Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation have a pending action against the United States related to fair dealings after the construction of the Grand Coulee Dam. The United States has negotiated a Settlement Agreement with the Tribe, contingent on enabling legislation for approval and ratification. Upon the enactment of this Act, the Settlement Agreement will provide compensation for past and future use of Colville Reservation land for electric power generation at Grand Coulee Dam, and settle the Tribe's claims against the United States under the Indian Claims Commission Act. The Commission Act approves and ratifies a Settlement Agreement between the United States and the Tribe, directing the Bonneville Power Administration to fulfill its obligations under the Agreement. SEC. 4. Approval, ratification, and implementation of settlement agreement between the United States and the Tribe. The Settlement Agreement is approved and ratified. The Bonneville Power Administration will make annual payments to the Tribe as per the agreement. The United States will join in the motion for a compromise final judgment of $53,000,000.00 in Confederated Tribes -o-f -C-o-l-v-i-l-l-e -R-e-s-e-r-v-a-t-i-o-n v. United States. The United States will pay the specified amount from appropriated funds and cannot be reimbursed by the Bonneville Power Administration. SEC. 5. DISTRIBUTION OF THE SETTLEMENT FUNDS. The lump sum payment under section 4(c)(1) is deposited in a trust fund for the Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation, to be used according to an approved distribution plan. Payments to minors are held in trust by the United States until the minor turns 18 or graduates from secondary school. The Secretary may authorize emergency use of trust funds for minors, in addition to annual payments made to the Tribe as per the Settlement Agreement. The Tribe can use these payments like any other income from natural resources. The Tribe can use these payments like any other income from natural resources. SEC. 6. REPAYMENT CREDIT. Beginning in fiscal year 2000, the Administrator will deduct 26 percent of the payment made to the Tribe from interest payable to the Treasury. This deduction will be credited towards interest payments due to the Treasury and allocated pro rata. The Administrator will deduct a percentage of payments made to the Tribe from interest payable to the Treasury starting in fiscal year 2000. This deduction will be allocated on a pro rata basis to interest payments on debt associated with the Federal Columbia River Power System's generation function. If the deduction exceeds the interest due on this debt, the excess amount will be credited towards other interest payments to the Treasury. SEC. 7. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS. Funds paid to the Tribe under the Settlement Agreement or this Act, along with any interest or income earned on those funds, are protected from federal or state levies, liens, or seizures. These funds cannot be considered as income for denying benefits to the Tribe or its members. The Act and Settlement Agreement do not affect the trust responsibility of the United States to the Tribe or its members.
